case_name: M/s. Jeewanlal 1929 Ltd. v. its workmen

facts.text: This appeal by special leave is directed against the award passed by the industrial tribunal under s. 36A(2) of the Industrial Disputes Act, 1947.

anchor.surface_text: Gajendragadkar, J. This appeal by special leave is directed against the award passed by the industrial tribunal in a matter which was referred to it under s. 36A 2  of the Industrial Disputes Act, 1947,

facts.text: The award interprets certain terms of the award made by the tribunal on April 28, 1951, in Reference No. 168 of 1950.

anchor.surface_text: for interpretation of certain terms of the award made by the said tribunal on April 28, 1951, in Reference No. 168 of 1950. It appears that a dispute had arisen between the appellant M s. Jeewanlal  1929  Ltd. and its workmen in regard to certain demands made by the respondents against the appellant in 1950.

facts.text: A dispute arose between appellant M/s. Jeewanlal (1929) Ltd. and its workmen regarding demands made in 1950.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that a dispute had arisen between the appellant M s. Jeewanlal  1929  Ltd. and its workmen in regard to certain demands made by the respondents against the appellant in 1950. The said dispute was referred for adjudication as a result of which an award was passed which, inter alia, provided for a gratuity scheme.

facts.text: The 1951 award provided for a gratuity scheme.

anchor.surface_text: The said dispute was referred for adjudication as a result of which an award was passed which, inter alia, provided for a gratuity scheme. Some provisions of this award have been referred for interpretation in the present reference.

facts.text: Resignation submitted by appellant's employee Bhanu Bala was accepted on August 31, 1957.

anchor.surface_text: On August 31, 1957, resignation submitted by the appellants employee Bhanu Bala was accepted by the appellant. The said employee had joined the appellants service in 1929 but there was a break in the companytinuity of his service for nearly 8 1/2 months because he had remained absent from duty without permission or leave from February 14, 1945 to the end of October, 1945.

facts.text: Bhanu Bala joined appellant's service in 1929.

anchor.surface_text: The said employee had joined the appellants service in 1929 but there was a break in the companytinuity of his service for nearly 8 1/2 months because he had remained absent from duty without permission or leave from February 14, 1945 to the end of October, 1945.

facts.text: Break in continuity of Bhanu Bala's service for nearly 8 1/2 months from February 14, 1945 to end of October 1945 due to absence without permission or leave.

anchor.surface_text: but there was a break in the companytinuity of his service for nearly 8 1/2 months because he had remained absent from duty without permission or leave from February 14, 1945 to the end of October, 1945. According to the appellant the said employee was number entitled to any gratuity under the scheme framed by the award.

facts.text: Appellant contended Bhanu Bala not entitled to gratuity due to break in service.

anchor.surface_text: According to the appellant the said employee was number entitled to any gratuity under the scheme framed by the award. Even so the appellant offered him Rs. 1,165 and odd on companypassionate grounds.

facts.text: Appellant offered Rs. 1,165 to Bhanu Bala on compassionate grounds.

anchor.surface_text: Even so the appellant offered him Rs. 1,165 and odd on companypassionate grounds. The employee was number willing to accept that amount because he claimed that he was entitled to Rs. 2,282.50 nP. by way of gratuity.

facts.text: Bhanu Bala claimed Rs. 2,282.50 as gratuity.

anchor.surface_text: The employee was number willing to accept that amount because he claimed that he was entitled to Rs. 2,282.50 nP. by way of gratuity. The demand thus made by the employee led to an industrial dispute which was taken by the employee before the First Labour Court at Bombay under s. 33C of the Act.

facts.text: Industrial dispute taken to First Labour Court at Bombay under s.33C(2) by Bhanu Bala.

anchor.surface_text: The demand thus made by the employee led to an industrial dispute which was taken by the employee before the First Labour Court at Bombay under s. 33C of the Act. The Labour Court entertained the application, decided the point in dispute in favour of the employee and directed the appellant to pay him Rs. 1,781.80 nP. as gratuity.

facts.text: Labour Court decided in favour of employee, directed payment of Rs. 1,781.80 as gratuity.

anchor.surface_text: The Labour Court entertained the application, decided the point in dispute in favour of the employee and directed the appellant to pay him Rs. 1,781.80 nP. as gratuity. The appellant then moved the Bombay High Court for a writ under Arts. 226 and 227 on the ground that the Labour Court had numberjurisdiction to entertain the application made before it by the employee.

facts.text: Appellant filed writ petition in Bombay High Court under Arts. 226 and 227 challenging Labour Court's jurisdiction.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant then moved the Bombay High Court for a writ under Arts. 226 and 227 on the ground that the Labour Court had numberjurisdiction to entertain the application made before it by the employee. This writ petition was allowed and the order passed by the Labour Court was quashed.

facts.text: Bombay High Court allowed writ petition and quashed Labour Court order.

anchor.surface_text: This writ petition was allowed and the order passed by the Labour Court was quashed. It was at this stage that the Government of Bombay referred the question of interpretation of the term companytinuous service companytained in the award of 1951 to the Industrial Court under s. 36A 1  of the Act.

facts.text: Government of Bombay referred interpretation of 'continuous service' in 1951 award to Industrial Court under s.36A(1).

anchor.surface_text: It was at this stage that the Government of Bombay referred the question of interpretation of the term companytinuous service companytained in the award of 1951 to the Industrial Court under s. 36A 1  of the Act. That is how the Industrial Court was possessed of the matter.

facts.text: Industrial Court held that 'continuous service' means service not broken or interrupted by termination of contract by employer/employee or operation of law.

anchor.surface_text: That is how the Industrial Court was possessed of the matter. It has held that the words companytinuous service as used by the tribunal when it framed the award in question mean service number broken or interrupted by the termination of the companytract of employment by either the employer or the employee or by operation of law.

facts.text: Gratuity scheme: On death or disability, half month's wages per year up to 10 months.

anchor.surface_text: The relevant part of the gratuity scheme which was framed by the tribunal in the earlier reference reads thus On the death of an employee while in the service of the companypany or on an employee becoming physically or mentally disabled to companytinue further in service half a months wages for each year of service subject to a maximum of ten months wages to be paid to him or to his heirs, executors, assigns or numberinees as the case may be.

facts.text: Gratuity scheme: On termination by company after 5 years continuous service, gratuity at same rate.

anchor.surface_text: On the termination of his service by companypany after five years companytinuous service - Gratuity at the same rate as above. On voluntary retirement or resignation of an employee after 15 years companytinuous service - Gratuity at the same rate as above.

facts.text: Gratuity scheme: On voluntary retirement or resignation after 15 years continuous service, gratuity at same rate.

anchor.surface_text: On voluntary retirement or resignation of an employee after 15 years companytinuous service - Gratuity at the same rate as above. As we have already seen the employee Bhanu Bala resigned and his resignation was accepted in August, 1957.

facts.text: Bhanu Bala claimed benefit of clause (iii) for resignation after 15 years continuous service.

anchor.surface_text: As we have already seen the employee Bhanu Bala resigned and his resignation was accepted in August, 1957. He claimed the benefit of clause  iii  whereas the appellant companytended that the said employee had number been employed in companytinuous service for the requisite period because there was a break in his service between February 14, 1945, to the end of October, 1945,

facts.text: Appellant contended that break in service from Feb 14, 1945 to end Oct 1945 affected continuity, making claim incompetent under clause (iii).

anchor.surface_text: whereas the appellant companytended that the said employee had number been employed in companytinuous service for the requisite period because there was a break in his service between February 14, 1945, to the end of October, 1945, and that affected the companytinuity of his employment which made his claim incompetent under clause  iii . This companytention has been rejected by the tribunal.

facts.text: Tribunal rejected appellant's contention on continuity.

anchor.surface_text: This companytention has been rejected by the tribunal. Mr. S. T. Desai companytends that in interpreting the words companytinuous service in clause  iii  we should companypare the provisions of s. 49B 1  along with the explanation in the Indian Factories Act, 1934  XXV of 1934  as well as s. 79 1  along with explanation  1  in the Indian Factories Act, 1948  63 of 1948  prior to its amendment in 1954

facts.text: Supreme Court affirms tribunal's view on continuous service with modification that long unauthorised absence may infer abandonment.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, therefore, the view taken by the tribunal is substantially right though we would like to make it clear that in addition to the cases where according to the tribunal companytinuity of service would companye to an end there would be the class of cases where long unauthorised absence may reasonably give rise to an inference that such service is intended to be abandoned by the employee. With this modification we companyfirm the award and dismiss the appeal.

issues.text: What is the correct interpretation of the term 'continuous service' as used by the tribunal in the gratuity scheme of the 1951 award?

anchor.surface_text: It has held that the words continuous service as used by the tribunal when it framed the award in question mean service not broken or interrupted by the termination of the contract of employment by either the employer or the employee or by operation of law. It is this interpretation the correctness of which is challenged by the appellant in its present appeal.

issues.text: Whether the provisions of s. 49B(1) of the Indian Factories Act, 1934 and s. 79(1) of the Indian Factories Act, 1948 should guide the interpretation of 'continuous service' such that unauthorised absence normally causes a break in service?

anchor.surface_text: Mr. S. T. Desai contends that in interpreting the words continuous service in clause iii we should compare the provisions of s. 49B 1 along with the explanation in the Indian Factories Act, 1934 XXV of 1934 as well as s. 79 1 along with explanation 1 in the Indian Factories Act, 1948 63 of 1948 prior to its amendment in 1954 and he argues that unauthorised absence from work should normally cause a break in service so that if an employee, after unauthorised absence from work, is allowed to resume after such unauthorised absence he should not be entitled to claim continuous service in view of the break in his service.

issues.text: Whether the definition of 'continuous service' in s. 2(eee) of the Industrial Disputes Act, 1947 applies to interpret the term in the award?

anchor.surface_text: The same comment falls to be made in regard to the argument based on the definition of the expression continuous service contained in s. 2 eee of the Industrial Disputes Act, 1947. The said section provides that continuous service means uninterrupted service and includes service which may be interrupted merely on account of sickness or authorised leave or an accident or a strike which is not illegal, or a lockout or a cessation of work which is not due to any fault on the part of the workmen.

issues.text: Whether mere absence without leave brings to an end the continuity of service by terminating the master-servant relationship?

anchor.surface_text: Continuous service in the context of the scheme of gratuity framed by the tribunal in the earlier reference postulates the continuance of the relationship of master and servant between the employer and his employees. ... but it is difficult to hold that merely because an employee is absent without obtaining leave that itself would bring to an end the continuity of his service.

issues.text: Whether mere participation in an illegal strike causes a break in continuity of service for gratuity purposes?

anchor.surface_text: Similarly, participation in an illegal strike which may incur the punishment of dismissal may not by itself bring to an end the relationship of master and servant. It may be a good cause for the termination of service provided of course the relevant provisions in the standing orders in that behalf are complied with but mere participation in an illegal strike cannot be said to cause breach in continuity for the purposes of gratuity.

issues.text: Whether long unauthorised absence can legitimately cause a break in continuity of service by inference of abandonment?

anchor.surface_text: On the other hand, if an employee continues to be absent from duty without obtaining leave and in an unauthorised manner for such a long period of time that an inference may reasonably be drawn from such absence that by his absence he has abandoned service, then such long unauthorised absence may legitimately be held to cause a break in the continuity of service.

holdings.text: The view taken by the tribunal on the meaning of 'continuous service' is substantially right, with the modification that long unauthorised absence may reasonably give rise to an inference of abandonment of service.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, therefore, the view taken by the tribunal is substantially right though we would like to make it clear that in addition to the cases where according to the tribunal companytinuity of service would companye to an end there would be the class of cases where long unauthorised absence may

holdings.reasoning_summary: Tribunal's interpretation aligns with continuance of master-servant relationship; adds abandonment exception based on factual inference.

holdings.text: The meaning attributed to 'continuous service' in the context of the Factories Act does not have material bearing on its interpretation in the award.

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, the meaning attributed to the words companytinuous service in the companytext of the Factories Act may number have a material bearing in deciding the point in the present appeal. The same companyment falls to be made in regard to the argument based

holdings.reasoning_summary: Words have context-dependent meanings; cites Budge Budge Municipality; Factories Act decision turned on specific strike definition.

holdings.text: The statutory definition of 'continuous service' in s.2(eee) of the Industrial Disputes Act cannot be automatically extended to interpret the term in the award unless context justifies.

anchor.surface_text: This definition is undoubtedly relevant in dealing with the question of companytinuous service by reference to the provisions of Industrial Disputes Act but its operation cannot be automatically extended in dealing with an interpretation of the words companytinuous service

holdings.reasoning_summary: Award interpretation requires examination on principle where no specific definition provided; statutory definitions from other contexts not binding.

holdings.text: 'Continuous service' in the gratuity scheme postulates continuance of master-servant relationship, broken by resignation, termination by employer, or operation of law.

anchor.surface_text: Continuous service in the companytext of the scheme of gratuity framed by the tribunal in the earlier reference postulates the companytinuance of the relationship of master and servant between the employer and his employees. If the servant resigns his employment service automatically companyes

holdings.reasoning_summary: Purposive interpretation of gratuity scheme focuses on ongoing employment relationship; identifies specific acts terminating it.

holdings.text: Merely being absent without obtaining leave does not bring to an end the continuity of service.

anchor.surface_text: but it is difficult to hold that merely because an employee is absent without obtaining leave that itself would bring to an end the companytinuity of his service. Similarly, participation in an illegal strike which may incur the punishment of dismissal

holdings.reasoning_summary: Absence alone does not terminate master-servant relationship without affirmative act.

holdings.text: Mere participation in an illegal strike does not cause a breach in continuity for gratuity purposes.

anchor.surface_text: Similarly, participation in an illegal strike which may incur the punishment of dismissal may number by itself bring to an end the relationship of master and servant. It may be a good cause for the termination of service provided of companyrse the relevant provisions

holdings.reasoning_summary: Requires compliance with standing orders for termination; participation alone insufficient to end relationship.

holdings.text: Long unauthorised absence may legitimately cause a break in continuity if it reasonably infers abandonment of service; a question of fact per case.

anchor.surface_text: On the other hand, if an employee companytinues to be absent from duty without obtaining leave and in an unauthorised manner for such a long period of time that an inference may reasonably be drawn from such absence that by his absence he has abandoned service,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Balances duration and intent; inference from facts determines if absence equates to termination by abandonment.

holdings.text: With the modification regarding abandonment inference, the tribunal's award is confirmed and the appeal dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: With this modification we companyfirm the award and dismiss the appeal.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Substantial affirmation of lower court's interpretation applied to facts; modification clarifies scope without altering outcome.

outcome.relief_summary: Appeal dismissed; tribunal's award confirmed with modification to the interpretation of 'continuous service' allowing for inference of service abandonment in cases of long unauthorised absence.
